resources.string:
The main town of Wołomin County in the Masovian Voivodship. A suburb of Warsaw situated 20 km from the capital of Poland, near the railway to Białystok. 

It has approximately 37,000 inhabitants and covers an area of 17 sq km (6 sq mi). 

Although the town is relatively young and most of the town's inhabitants commute to Warsaw on a daily basis, there are a few places to see and interesting people to meet here.

Wołomin was first mentioned in chronicles from the 15th century. It remained a small village in central Masovia without much significance. Since 19th century, and especially after the foundation of the railway in 1862, Wołomin became a summer holiday destination for Warsaw citizens. The Wołomin glassworks were founded in the beginning of the 20th century. 
 
Wołomin was declared a town in 1919 after the return of Poland's sovereignty. In 1920 the Polish counter-attack in the Battle of Warsaw was conducted near Wołomin. In the interbellum Wołomin retained its status as a multinational town. There was a big Jewish and Russian minority. Polish writer Zofia Nałkowska had a house in Wołomin, which became an inspiration for her 1925 book House over meadows (Polish: Dom nad łąkami). 
 
During World War II, the Jews of Wołomin were forced into a ghetto set up by Nazi German administration on 15 November 1940, along the railway line between the streets of Kobyłkowska, Wspólna, Wiejska, Glinka and Cementowa. The ghetto inmates numbered about 2,700 people including Jews expelled from other locations. The Judenrat was established in the building at 17 Nałkowskiego Street. Deportations aboard Holocaust trains to Treblinka extermination camp began on 19 August 1942. The ghetto was liquidated on 6 October 1942. A few hundred people (416-620 according to different sources) were shot in the ghetto, including many elderly and sick people. Their bodies were buried in a mass grave near the Korsaka Road. Some Jews were deported to the Warsaw Ghetto as slave labour and exterminated during the Grossaktion Warsaw. 
 
After the war, Wołomin became a capital of the powiat of Wołomin and started to grow rapidly. The window assembly plant was founded and Wołomin soon became a suburb of Warsaw.

Middle Eastern and Kurdish cuisine: kebabs – on plate and sandwiches, koftas. Meat and vegetarian food. Beer. 
 
Mon–Fri: 10 am – 11 pm 
Sat: 10 am – 1 am 
Sun: 9 am – 12 pm

American and European cuisine: hamburgers and chips. Usually (after supply) many regional beers. 
 
Mon–Thu: 1 pm – 10 pm 
Fri: 1 pm – 11 pm 
Sat: 12 am – 11 pm 
Sun: 12 am – 10 pm

East Mediterranean street food: vegetarian with a lot of dishes for meat lovers too. 
 
Mon–Sat: 11 am – 10 pm 
Sun: 12 am – 10 pm

European mix cuisine. A lunch of a day. A few of regional beers in the menu – always ask a waiter. 
 
Mon–Thu: 9 am – 10 pm 
Fri: 9 am – 12 pm 
Sat: 12 am – 10 pm 
Sun: 12 am – 9 pm

Balkan cuisine, mainly Greek, Croatian and Bulgarian. A lot of wines to choose. 
 
Mon–Thu: 11 am – 10 pm 
Fri: 11 am – 11 pm 
Sat: 12 am – 10 pm 
Sun: 12 am – 9 pm

Polish traditional lunches and dinners. A special offer for a lunch of a day (soup and main dish). 
 
Mon–Fri: 10 am – 6 pm 
Sat–Sun: closed

Frying Polish traditional food, dumplings and meat dishes. 
 
Mon–Fri: 11 am – 7 pm 
Sat: 12 am – 6 pm
Sun: closed
Thai and Vietnamese cuisine with Polish ingredients. Almost nothing to drink. \n \nMon–Sun: 11 am – 9 pm
Polish version of Italian cuisine: pizzas. \n\nSun–Thu 11 am – 10 pm, Fri–Sat 11 am – 11 pm

Italian cuisine: pizzas, pastas and salads. Poor selections of drinks. 

Mon–Thu 11 am – 10 pm 
Fri–Sat 11 am – 11 pm, 
Sun 12 am – 10 pm

For locals – just “Ryba”. A pub for heavy music, motorcycle and fishing lovers. A lot of different Polish beers and a few stronger alcohols. On one Tuesday in a month – evenings only for ladies. Concerts and exhibitions.
A place for fans of dance, hip hop and rap. Disco and karaoke. Only beer to drink, snacks to eat. Younger spirit of the town.
A place for football fans. Evening with matched on TV. The legendary pub of local mafia\’s duels. Closed after shooting in 2011, renewed and opened again under different name.
A pub for real natives – a bit older town’s inhabitants. Relatively cheap beer. Open only till 10 pm. Do you want to feel the climate of a small town? You have to show up here.
Feel the climate of ‘80! An old-fashioned hotel with a communistic atmosphere. Rooms with or without bathrooms, TV, radio, internet. A small restaurant for guests in the building.
A hostel – the cheapest bed and breakfast in the town. Quite good conditions as for the price. 24/7 shop with alcohol downstairs. A bit noisy also because the main road in the front of the building.

A hotel with many years of tradition. Situared almost in the centre of the Town, but also quiet and calm. A restaurant for guests. Breakfast for 15 zł. Parking and wireless internet. They speak English!

“A hunter\’s home” – hostel situated on the borders of two towns: Wołomin and Kobyłka, nearby Grabicz park – unique bird’s preserve (look into “Go” category to find out more). A very quiet place. Speciality of the house: home-made bread.

Exclusive hotel near Wołomin with climate coming from 17th, 18th and 19th century. SPA, jacuzzi and museum. A restaurant “Dwór Rozłogi” with traditional Polish and hunt\’s dishes for all guests. Forest nearby.

Remember the story about three pigs? This unusual green house built by the owners themselves with straw, clay and wood surely survive more than that. How to build in harmony with nature? Come and inspire yourself. Visits only by appointments.

A cinema in good, old style. Something for those, who don’t like modern multiplexes, but like contemporary movies. You won’t drink here a fancy coffee, but seeing cinema\’s beautiful old-fashioned wooden floor it\’s worth this sacrifice!

A biographical museum dedicated to an esteemed geographer, a father of Polish modern geography Wacław Nałkowski and his daughter Zofia, a famous Polish writer. “House at the Fields”, as it was called by Zofia while she was living here, today is full of souvenirs of them.

A small village south of Wołomin – in 1920 a witness of the famous battle of Warsaw, which refers to the decisive Polish victory during the Polish–Soviet War. Poland repulsed and defeated the invading Red Army. Cemetery from 1920 and monuments to Polish and Russian victims of battle of Ossów.

An old wooden house built in the typical style for a summer resorts in the Masovia region before World War II, but with completely different purpose. In 1930–1937 it was an orthodox chapel of St. St. Peter and Paul.
Take the photo of the all Warsaw’s skyscrapers. You have to be lucky to get inside the right block house to get this view. But sometimes it\’s really good to look from the perspective.

Founded in 1978 on marsh and wetlands in the south of Wołomin to protect rare species of birds and mammals. Area of the preserve is mostly closed for tourist – they can only take a walk along two paths: western and north one. But seeing all those fauna is totally worth it.
